entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} do trafienia, zasięg 5 stóp, jeden cel. {@h}brak obrażeń, ale celowi musi się udać {@dc 15} ratunek przed Mądrością lub doznać poniższych efektów, zależnych od rodzaju dreamwraka:
{@i Anxiety:} Śniący jest ogarnięty strachem i rozpaczą, cierpi na minusy przy sprawdzaniu zdolności, ratowaniu i atakowaniu przez {@dice 1d4} godzin.
{@i Erotic:} Śniący zyskuje warunek {@condition charmed} na {@dice 2d6} dni z pierwszą istotą, do której jest romantycznie przyciągany, którą widzi służącą za zaklinacza.
{@i Nightmare:} Śniący zyskuje {@condition frightened} kondycję wobec każdej napotkanej istoty przez następne {@dice 1d4} godziny.

action.name: Etherealness
entries: Dreamwrack wchodzi na Płaszczyznę Eteryczną z Płaszczyzny Materialnej lub odwrotnie. Jest widoczny na Płaszczyźnie Materialnej, gdy znajduje się na Granicznej Eterycznej i odwrotnie, jednak nie może wpłynąć ani być dotknięty przez nic na drugiej płaszczyźnie.

Dreamwracks występują w trzech odmianach - koszmarnej, erotycznej i lękowej - w zależności od natury snu, z którego powstały. Kiedy pojawiają się na planie fizycznym, ich formy są cienistą kolekcją zmieniających się obrazów zaczerpniętych ze snu, z którego dreamwrack się narodził, wzywając głosy imitujące przyjaciół, wrogów i ukochanych celu. Ci, którzy są świadkami manifestacji dreamwracka, otrzymują wgląd w podświadomość śniącego.

entries.name: Delving too deep into Dreams
entries: Wśród błękitnych lotosów kapłana Eriasa, półboga snów, krążą opowieści o niezadowoleniu półboga z tych śmiertelników, którzy zbyt głęboko wkraczają w jego sferę. Śmiertelnicy, którzy chcieliby naruszyć materię snów, mogą spotkać się z tym, że ich sny powrócą do nich na jawie. Dreamwracks to duchy powstające, gdy sfera snów zostaje zakłócona przez magię. Na wpół uformowana tkanka zaburzonych snów nie rozpuszcza się. Zamiast tego, łączy się w amalgamat obrazów sennych, który jest związany z osobą, z której snu pęknięcie zostało uformowane. Z pewnością oniromanci ze Skarbca Filakterii w Darakeene mogą zaświadczyć, że są nawiedzani przez pęknięcia snów, gdy zagłębiają się w królestwo Eriasa.

entries.name: Misguided hunger
entries: Po uformowaniu, dreamwrack empatycznie szuka swojego połączonego z nim śniącego w świecie fizycznym, przyciągnięty przez swoją potrzebę i podświadomą potrzebę śniącego, aby rozwiązać sen, z którego dreamwrack powstał. Dreamwrack jest napędzany do działań, które nawiedzają i niepokoją śniącego. Jedynym celem dreamwracka jest zamanifestowanie uczuć i stanu umysłu śniącego, które miał podczas tworzenia snu, tym samym kończąc sen. Czasami wymaga to "nawiedzania" śniącego przez wiele tygodni; czasami jest to rozwiązane podczas jednej wizyty.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Dreamwrack nie angażuje się w walkę per se, choć z pewnością może zostać przez nią zniszczony. Jeśli zostanie zraniony, instynktownie zmieni się w eterycznego i ucieknie. Śniący nawiedza śniącego, dopóki ten nie znajdzie się w sytuacji podobnej do tej, w której znajdował się sen, który go stworzył, po czym manifestuje się i używa ataku emocji. Dreamwrack odejdzie, gdy odtworzy sen, który go stworzył lub zostanie zabity.

resist.note: from nonmagical weapons that aren't silvered

trait.name: Dream Telepathy
entries: Upiory senne mogą rozmawiać tylko z istotami zdolnymi do śnienia. Komunikaty te manifestują się jako żywe obrazy i dźwięki ze snów lub marzeń dziennych.

trait.name: Dreamsight
entries: Dreamwraiths potrafią wyczuć obecność każdej istoty zdolnej do śnienia, nawet jeśli jest niewykrywalna wzrokiem.

trait.name: Dreamslip
entries: Za pomocą dotyku, dreamwraith może próbować wejść w sny danej istoty, żywiąc się jej psychiką i ukrytymi emocjami. Jeśli celowi nie uda się {@dc 17} rzut ratunkowy na mądrość, wtedy dreamwraith łączy się z nim. Cel natychmiast zapada w głęboki sen, który jest pełen żywych snów. Sen ten przynosi ulepszone naturalne uzdrowienie; dotknięta nim istota zyskuje korzyść z długiego odpoczynku już po 4 godzinach snu. Wszelkie próby obudzenia dotkniętego stworzenia mają minus. Elfy i inne stworzenia, które nie śpią, są odporne na ten efekt.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: Dreamwraith może poruszać się przez inne istoty i obiekty tak, jakby były trudnym terenem. Otrzymuje 5 ({@damage 1d10}) obrażeń od siły, jeśli zakończy swoją turę wewnątrz obiektu.

trait.name: Merge with Illusion
entries: Dreamwraith może połączyć się z zaklęciem iluzji, aby zwiększyć jej wiarygodność; każdy, kto próbuje nie wierzyć w iluzję, ma minus do rzutów ratujących. W przypadku zaklęć o przedłużonym czasie trwania, dreamwraith oddziałuje na nie maksymalnie przez jeden dzień.

action.name: Psychic Drain
entries: Jeśli dreamwraith dotknie jakiejś istoty, musi ona wykonać ratujący ją test na charyzmę {@dc 17} lub otrzymać 36 ({@damage 8d8}) obrażeń psychicznych. Maksymalny hit point celu jest zmniejszony o tę wartość do czasu zakończenia krótkiego lub długiego odpoczynku. Cel ma również minusy w testach zdolności Charisma i rzutach ratunkowych, dopóki redukcja punktów trafień nie zostanie usunięta. Jeśli celowi się powiedzie, otrzymuje połowę obrażeń i żadnych dodatkowych efektów.

Dreamwraiths to druga najpotężniejsza grupa elementali, która służy Eriasowi, półbogowi snów. Kiedy Erias zdecyduje, że śmiertelnicy zbyt mocno naruszyli świętość jego królestwa snów, a koszmary wywołane przez takie wtargnięcie nie są wystarczającą karą, bóg wysyła dreamwraiths, by rozliczały śpiących śmiertelników z ich czynów. Upiory senne mogą również przyprowadzać śmiertelników do Erias na audiencję. Zazwyczaj takimi śmiertelnikami są kapłani Eriasa lub iluzjoniści, którzy zaskarbili sobie przychylność boga. Erias udziela im rad lub zleca im misję w swoim imieniu.

entries.name: Creatures of Dreams
entries: Jak większość innych żywiołów służących Eriasowi, dreamwraiths nie są tworzone z dusz zmarłych śmiertelników, ale raczej z samych snów. Są ucieleśnieniem snów i koszmarów, którym półbóg nadał formę i zdolność odczuwania. Po przybyciu na plan fizyczny, upiory przybierają upiorną, powoli zmieniającą się postać, niczym kłębiąca się mgła. Starożytni czarodzieje ze Scarn jako pierwsi odkryli, wezwali i związali dreamwraiths do swojej woli, a iluzjoniści nadal wzywają te stworzenia, aby wzmocnić swoje iluzje.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Dreamwraith unikają bezpośredniego ataku, wolą łączyć się z celami poprzez dreamlip i żywić się ich emocjami. Jeśli zostanie zmuszony do walki, dreamwraith używa swojego psychicznego drenażu.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: Rój ma przewagę w rolkach ataku wręcz przeciwko każdej istocie, która nie ma wszystkich swoich punktów trafień.

trait.name: Sand Swimmers
entries: Wydrzyki mogą pływać przez piasek tak jak ryby pływają przez wodę, ale nie mogą poruszać się przez litą skałę lub ubitą ziemię. Są w stanie oddychać podczas pływania po piasku. Mogą użyć akcji bonusowej do Dash, o ile poruszają się w linii prostej.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: Rój może zajmować przestrzeń innego stworzenia i odwrotnie, a także rój może poruszać się przez każdy otwór wystarczająco duży dla gada Tiny. Rój nie może odzyskać punktów trafień ani zyskać tymczasowych punktów trafień.

action.name: Bites
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} do trafienia, zasięg 0 stóp, jedno stworzenie w przestrzeni roju. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) obrażeń przebijających lub 7 ({@damage 2d6}) obrażeń przebijających, jeśli rój ma połowę punktów trafień lub mniej.

Choć nazywane są rybami, to w rzeczywistości są to gady o gładkiej skórze, z długim wijącym się ogonem i krótkimi, pajęczymi stopami. Pływając w pobliżu powierzchni piasku, szukają zdobyczy. Kiedy ją znajdą, skaczą z powierzchni, atakując swoimi maleńkimi zębami.

entries.name: Desert Schools
entries: Nie jest pewne, co przyciąga te maleńkie gady, poza rannymi stworzeniami. Niektórzy twierdzą, że jest to zapach żywych istot, inni, że wibracje, które ludzie wytwarzają przemierzając wydmy, a jeszcze inni wierzą, że przyciąga je strach i desperacja zagubionych na pustyni. Niektórzy koczownicy podążają za ławicami wydm, polując na nie dla pożywienia (choć może to być niebezpieczne) lub by odzyskać skarby pozostawione, gdy wydmy zaatakują karawanę lub inną grupę.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Ryby pływają tuż pod powierzchnią piasku, powodując charakterystyczne falowanie, które może ostrzec o ich zbliżaniu się za pomocą udanego testu mądrości (przetrwania) DC 18. Gdy znajdą ofiarę, otaczają ją i atakują bezlitośnie, dopóki nie skończą się pożywiać. Ignorują wszelkie skarby i szybko ruszają w poszukiwaniu kolejnego posiłku.

trait.name: Fearless Loyalty
entries: Kiedy krasnoludzki ogar widzi, że inne stworzenie podejmuje wrogie działania w stosunku do swojego pana, zyskuje przewagę w rolkach ataku, sprawdzaniu umiejętności i rzutach ratunkowych przeciwko temu stworzeniu lub jego specjalnym zdolnościom tak długo, jak długo trwa postrzegane zagrożenie.

trait.name: Ore Nose
entries: Krasnoludzki ogar potrafi wyczuć rudę lub metal, tak jak ogar wyczuwa żywe istoty, i ma przewagę w testach Mądrości (Percepcji), które polegają na tej zdolności.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} do trafienia, zasięg 5 stóp, jeden cel. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) obrażeń przebijających. Jeśli cel jest istotą, musi odnieść sukces w rzucie ratunkowym na {@dc 12} Wytrzymałość lub zostać powalony {@condition prone}.

action.name: Deafening Bark
entries: Wszystkie stworzenia w promieniu 45 stóp muszą wykonać {@dc 12} rzut ratunkowy na Konstytucję. W przypadku porażki stworzenie otrzymuje 5 ({@damage 2d4}) obrażeń od piorunów, lub połowę obrażeń w przypadku sukcesu, i jest {@condition deafened} do końca swojej następnej tury. Stworzenie, które nie zdoła wykonać rzutu ratunkowego o 5 lub więcej, jest również {@condition stunned} do końca swojej następnej tury.

{@i My dearest Margeaux: my business with the dwarves is nearly concluded, and I shall soon be returning to the sunshine and your arms. I have seen many wonders of which I am eager to tell you, but for now let me just say that never again will I complain to the neighbors about their barking hounds...}

Nazwa psa karłowatego pochodzi od jego hodowców, a nie od jego postury. Jego potężna sylwetka jest szeroka i krępa, a krótka czarna sierść pokryta jest czerwono-złotymi plamami na pysku, klatce piersiowej i brzuchu. Jego duże złote oczy błyszczą w cieniu tunelu lub jaskini.

entries.name: Marvel of Dwarven Engineering
entries: Legendy mówią, że ludzki król Darakeene podarował królowi Thorvannowi tuzin cennych mastifów w geście wdzięczności za pomoc krasnoludów podczas inwazji goblinów. Dar był w dużej mierze symboliczny, gdyż krasnoludy nie są znanymi hodowcami psów gończych, ale Thorvann był pod wielkim wrażeniem psów i rozpoczął próby udoskonalenia rasy. W rezultacie, wiele pokoleń później, powstała nieprawdopodobna mieszanka psiej lojalności i siły połączona z krasnoludzką pasją do głębokich, ciemnych miejsc i żył błyszczącej rudy.

entries.name: Awaken the Dead
entries: Karłowate psy gończe są hodowane dla rozumu i odwagi, i zazwyczaj mają ogromną siłę i wytrzymałość. Nie są szybkimi biegaczami, ale mogą się przedzierać przez bardzo wąskie przejścia i podążać za swoimi panami niezmordowanym kłusem. Ich najbardziej godną uwagi cechą fizyczną jest jednak rozdzierający uszy szczek, który jest naprawdę gorszy od ich zgryzu: znany jest z tego, że potrafi rozbijać kamienie i odbijać się echem na wiele mil w podziemnych korytarzach.

entries.name: A Nose for Gold
entries: Ich inną niezwykłą cechą, mniej widoczną dla postronnych i w dużej mierze utrzymywaną w tajemnicy, jest umiejętność wyczuwania metali, zarówno szlachetnych, jak i zwykłych. Górnicy często wykorzystują krasnoludzkie psy gończe do wywęszenia żył rudy głęboko w górach lub do śledzenia uciekinierów i wrogów po przedmiotach, które noszą.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Ogar krasnoludzki jest całkowicie nieustraszony w obronie swojego pana i nie cofnie się przed żadnym napastnikiem, niezależnie od jego wielkości i niebezpieczeństwa. Większość z nich została wyszkolona do nieustannego szczekania na zaklinaczy, podobnie jak w kierunku podejrzanych, niewidzialnych przeciwników, zwłaszcza tych, którzy wydzielają zapach metalu.

monster.name: Emperor Stag
languages: can speak with any beast of its domain
and understands but is unable to speak elven and human languages

trait.name: Blur of Speed
entries: Ataki z Okazji przeciwko jeleniowi lub jego jeźdźcowi są wykonywane z minusem.

trait.name: Run Like the Wind
entries: W nocy jeleń może szybko pokonać duże odległości. Jeźdźcowi, czy też mijanemu po drodze obserwatorowi, wydaje się, że jeleń galopuje równie szybko jak szybki koń, ale magia Deneva pozwala mu pokonywać sto lig na godzinę.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: Jeleń cesarski porusza się w linii prostej, ale po przebyciu co najmniej 20 stóp może przejść przez przestrzeń zajmowaną przez średnie lub mniejsze stworzenia. Każde stworzenie na jego drodze może wykorzystać swoją reakcję, aby wykonać test {@dc 20} Wytrzymałości (Atletyka); jeśli się powiedzie, ruch jelenia zostaje zatrzymany. Jeśli jeleń nie zostanie zatrzymany, stworzenie musi wykonać {@dc 18} rzut ratujący zręczność albo zostanie powalone {@condition prone} i otrzyma 14 ({@damage 4d6}) obrażeń od obrażeń kłutych.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Jeleń cesarski wykonuje dwa ataki kopytami i jeden atak porożem.

action.name: Antler Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} do trafienia, zasięg 5 stóp, jeden cel. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) obrażeń przebijających.

action.name: Hoof
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} do trafienia, zasięg 5 stóp, jeden cel. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) obrażeń od uderzenia.

reaction.name: Antler Parry
entries: Gdy zostanie zaatakowany atakiem bronią do walki wręcz, jako reakcja jeleń dodaje 4 do swojego AC przeciwko temu atakowi, potencjalnie powodując chybienie.

{@i Devrie was old—she had spent nearly eight decades defending the forest and a cold night like this made her bones ache and reminded her that soon a spring would come that she would not see. But for now, the recruits looked at her expectantly, their faces lit by the low-burning fire.}
{@i "A story?" she repeated. There, in the darkness, a large shape caught her eye. None of the young folk had seen it. "Aye, I'll tell you about the Emperor Stag who lives in these here woods..."}

Majestatyczny jeleń cesarski ma duże, inteligentne oczy i bogate futro, które lśni w półmroku pod starymi drzewami. Jego poroże rozpościera się jak gałęzie czcigodnego dębu i błyszczy jak wypolerowane żelazo.

entries.name: Envoy of the Earth Goddess
entries: Ten duch rządzi głębokimi lasami i utrzymuje prawa drewna na rozkaz Denev, Matki Ziemi, przemierzając swoją domenę z prędkością wiatru, aby służyć jej woli. Jeleń jest w stanie mówić językami wszystkich zwierząt żyjących w lesie, z których wiele działa jako jego oczy i uszy, przekazując mu informacje o tym, co dzieje się w jego królestwie. Jeleń cesarski obserwuje podróżnych i odpłaca za ich czyny: akty miłosierdzia są nagradzane, a akty przemocy są w pełni opłacane.

entries.name: Reluctant Steed
entries: Legenda głosi, że bohater, który złapie bezwiednie cesarskiego jelenia, wskoczy na jego grzbiet i wyszepcze cel podróży, zostanie zabrany tam w ciągu jednej nocy, bez względu na odległość. Wątpliwe jest, czy ten czyn jest rzeczywiście tak prosty, a w każdym razie sługa bogini jest co najwyżej niechętnym wierzchowcem: może posłusznie nieść bohatera zgodnie z poleceniem, ale nie składa obietnic co do bezpieczeństwa podróży.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Jeleń walczy odważnie, ale z cierpliwością i inteligencją. W razie potrzeby użyje szarży depczącej w kilku rzutach przeciwko grupom, ale przeciwko potężnemu pojedynczemu przeciwnikowi najpierw użyje szarży, by powalić cel na ziemię, a następnie zaatakuje porożem i kopytami. W razie wyraźnej przewagi, jeleń może zebrać stado leśnych zwierząt lub nawet drzewo {@creature willow tree warrior|SLCC|willow tree warriors}, by mu pomóc.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Fatling jest 10-poziomowym czarodziejem. Jego zdolnością zaklęcia jest Mądrość (spell save {@dc 15}, lub {@hit 7} do trafienia z atakami zaklęciami). Ma przygotowane następujące zaklęcia druidów:

trait.name: Disease Immunity
entries: Tułacz jest odporny na choroby.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: Tułacz jest odporny na wszelkie zaklęcia i efekty, które mogłyby zmienić jego formę.

trait.name: Lard Worms
entries: Stworzenie {@condition grappled} przy tułaczu otrzymuje 14 ({@damage 4d6}) obrażeń od kwasu od robaków smalcowych na początku tury tułacza.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} do trafienia, zasięg 5 stóp, jeden cel. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) obrażeń od obrażeń kłutych, a cel jest {@condition grappled} (ucieczka {@dc 14}). Jeśli cel jest Średni lub mniejszy, jest również {@condition restrained} do czasu zakończenia tego chwytania. Podczas chwytania tego celu, fatling ma przewagę w rolkach ataku przeciwko niemu i nie może użyć tego ataku przeciwko innym stworzeniom. Kiedy fatling się porusza, Medium lub mniejsza istota, którą chwyta, porusza się z nim.

W czasie Boskiej Wojny bogowie uwięzili Gauraka Gorgera pod ziemią, ale to nie znaczy, że jego nikczemny wpływ nie może być nadal odczuwalny na Blizkich Ziemiach. Najbardziej ulubieni słudzy Gauraka są błogosławieni przez swego pochowanego pana. Łaska Gauraka jest jasna dla tych, którzy wiedzą, czego szukać: Gdzieś w pobliżu kapliczki wyznawcy wyrasta nagle plama żółtaczkowych, tłustych owoców, warzyw lub jadalnych grzybów. Zjedzenie tych odrażających rzeczy zmienia druidycznego czciciela w odbicie samego Gauraka.

entries.name: Scions of Gaurak
entries: Sługa staje się grubasem, groteskowo otyłym monstrum, wokół którego gromadzą się inni wyznawcy tytana, by odprawiać swoje obrzydliwe rytuały w nadziei na pozyskanie przychylności pogrzebanego tytana. Mimo, że grubasek może być odrażający, wyznawcy Gauraka, którzy czczą tę istotę, oddadzą życie, by chronić wybrańców tytana.

entries.name: Foul Though and Through
entries: Grubasy są nieludzko odrażające, mają dosłownie wałki na wałkach tłustej, nieświeżej, żółtej skóry. Nieustannie pocą się śmierdzącym, śliskim olejem, który pozwala im ślizgać się po ciele, jeśli w ogóle zdecydują się poruszać - są bowiem tak otyli, że ledwo mogą poruszać własnymi nogami. Grubasy otrzymują dodatkowy dar w postaci robaków smalcowych (patrz ramka), stworzeń, które zamieszkują fałdy kapłanów i zjadają wszystko, co może być w nich uwięzione, w tym rozkładające się kawałki ciała, które grubasy rutynowo zrzucają z siebie.

entries.name: Lard Worm Infestation
entries: Just as some fish have a symbiotic relationship with larger predator fish, so do lard worms have a symbiotic relationship with fatlings. Around 8 to 10 inches long and half an inch thick, lard worms live deep in the folds and recesses of fatlings' mounds of flesh, cleaning away the various unwholesome substances (including smothered victims' bodies) that accumulate there. One active fatling can host several hundred worms. Lard worms almost always attack creatures enveloped by a fatling, since their bite makes it more likely that the creature dies there and thus becomes food for the entire colony. Individually, lard worms are Tiny vermin with 1 hit point each.

entries.name: Sample Fatling
entries: This example of a fatling uses a dwarf druid, increased to a 10th-level spellcaster. Its ability scores have been modified as well.

entries.name: Lore
entries: Fulthis Maruk was a dwarven druid of Denev, revering the Earth Mother. Part of an adventuring company, he accompanied his comrades into the deeps of the Perforated Plains in search of glory. Unfortunately, tragedy struck and his compatriots died, leaving him distraught and alone in the wilderness. Delirious from disease and hunger, Fulthis found his way into the Gluttonous Caves north of the Plains.

Ravenous, he found a subterranean patch of mushrooms and fell on them, staving off starvation. A short time after, a voice awakened him—it was the voice of his own hunger, but it spoke to him in the words of Gaurak, saying only, "Feed." He has come to be known only as the "Bloat Beneath the Caves," ruling a small tribe of titanspawn from his lair within a tiny section of the Gluttonous Caves.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Although fatlings may seem defenseless, they're actually quite dangerous. Many weapons cannot harm them, thanks to the creatures' excessive tissue. They are also highly resistant to magic, and anyone who gets too close can be pinned and suffocated under layers of blubber. Finally, Fulthis Maruk draws power from Gaurak, and has a varity of spells at his disposal, which he will use to attack any enemies.

entries.name: Fatling Template
entries: Any neutral or evil humanoid can become a fatling, provided it is able to cast druid or sorcerer spells. A creature that becomes a fatling retains all its statistics except as noted below.

entries.name: Size
entries: The fatling's size increases by one category, to a minimum of Large.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The fatling's alignment is always neutral evil.

entries.name: Speed
entries: The fatling's speed is reduced to 10 feet. Its speed cannot be reduced further (such as by difficult terrain), nor can it benefit from any bonus to its speed.

entries.name: Damage Resistances
entries: The fatling has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical weapons.

entries.name: Disease Immunity
entries: Tułacz jest odporny na choroby.

entries.name: Poison Immunity
entries: The fatling is immune to poison damage and to being poisoned.

entries.name: Senses
entries: A fatling gains darkvision out to 60 feet, or the range of its darkvision increases by 30 feet if it already had darkvision.

entries.name: Immutable Form
entries: Tułacz jest odporny na wszelkie zaklęcia i efekty, które mogłyby zmienić jego formę.

entries.name: Lard Worms
entries: Fatlings are infested with colonies of lard worms, horrific creatures that feed off the rotting flesh that collects in the corpulent folds of the fatling. A creature grappled by a fatling also takes {@damage 4d6} acid damage from lard worms at the start of the fatling's turn each round.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The feral has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Packmind
entries: When a feral succeeds at a Perception check, all pack mates within 1 mile are considered to have succeeded at the same check.

trait.name: Packsoul
entries: When a feral dies, remaining members of the pack gain 4 temporary hit points, and these points are cumulative with any previous temporary hit points. For every three ferals that die, the survivors gain a +1 bonus to all attack rolls, damage, saving throws, ability checks, and saving throw DCs.

trait.name: Thrill of the Hunt
entries: When the feral takes the Dash action, scores a critical hit, or reduces an enemy to 0 hit points it can howl as a bonus action.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} do trafienia, zasięg 5 stóp, jeden cel. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) obrażeń od cięcia.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage, or 5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Howl
entries: Each creature within 60 ft. of the feral who can hear, and isn't already {@condition frightened} of the pack, must make a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of the pack until the end of its next turn. On a result of 20 or higher the creature is immune to this effect for the next 24 hours.
{@i "Another wretch falls to my sword! Who else wants some of that?"}
{@i "Hmm, tough little beggar."}
{@i "This one...doesn't want...to die."}
{@i "Warrior needs healing! Badly..."}
{@i (Crunching sounds)}
With horrible tusks and cloven hooves, the hulking man-beast strides forward, its wickedly jagged spear at the ready. A nearby howl signals the arrival of the rest of its pack.

entries.name: Vangal's Vengeance
entries: When seen in the Scarred Lands, ferals seldom have a purpose other than the utter destruction of anything in their path. They are dispatched at the whim of the demon god Vangal to please him with wanton murder and destruction. A pack of ferals that falls upon a village leaves naught but a crudely designed temple of gore and rubble to their god.

entries.name: Sundered Soul
entries: Chosen from the most brutish souls that make their way into the Abyssal Caldera that is Vangal's kingdom, a single soul is splintered into as many as sixteen parts, and from those a pack of ferals is formed. Forever bound to each other, if any of its members are destroyed, their vital energy simply flows back into the remaining pack members to make them stronger.

entries.name: Collective Consciousness
entries: A pack of ferals operates with one mind. All ferals of a pack who are within a mile of each other remain in constant telepathic and sensory communication: if one is aware of something, they all are.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Feral ‘tactics' aren't recognizable as such: they mostly just swarm over anything in their path and attack the nearest creature that isn't a pack mate. If out of combat range they will often howl while closing.

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The flailing dreadnought is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The flailing dreadnought's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The flailing dreadnought makes four attacks: one with its bite and three with its tentacles.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Flailing Burst {@recharge 4}
entries: The flailing dreadnought makes one tentacle attack against each creature it chooses within 15 feet of it. Attack rolls against the dreadnought have advantage until the start of its next turn.

Flailing dreadnoughts are huge metallic creatures with some bioorganic material mixed into their composition. They resemble huge floating eggs covered in segmented metal plates, with massive, fanged maws that can be extended like a shark's when biting. Dreadnoughts attack virtually anything that comes near them, particularly if it has metal on or about its person. They are thought to ingest some amount of metal ore or metallic goods occasionally, but it is unknown whether they do this out of necessity, habit, or for some other reason.

entries.name: Spawn of Golthagga
entries: The flailing dreadnoughts were the twisted creation of the Shaper. In the latter days of the Divine War, the titan created dozens of these creatures and threw them into battle to shred through the ranks of the divine armies. Now with their creator gone, those few flailing dreadnoughts that remain dwell in remote areas, especially underground near large concentrations of metal ore such as abandoned mines or ruined wasteland cities.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Created to be a weapon of war, the flailing dreadnought is a fierce, but not very bright opponent. It almost always rushes into combat, roaring and biting, and if it has several opponents near it unleashes its flailing burst as often as possible. Against fewer enemies, or those who try to maintain their distance, the dreadnought drags foes about the battlefield to place them wherever is most advantageous for itself.

trait.name: Foliage Camouflage
entries: The flay beast has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide among plants or other greenery.

action.name: Pounce {@recharge 5}
entries: The flay beast moves its entire distance and then makes both a bite attack and a claw attack with advantage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) piercing damage and the target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become

action.name: Poisoned
entries: The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the effect on a success.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 3d4 + 2}) slashing damage.

A flay beast resembles a man-sized praying mantis with the strong back legs and wings of a grasshopper. Despite their size, they possess only animal-level intelligence. Flay beats are relentless and vicious predators, willing to attack anything that they might have a chance of killing.

entries.name: Spawn of Hrinruuk
entries: Flay beasts are the spawn of Hrinruuk, conceived by the evil titan to attack and devour indiscriminately as he sometimes did. They provide no benefit to nature, other than to cull the weak, but their tenacity is such that they will kill an entire pack of animals, leaving no survivors and therefore no food for later. They readily turn on one another, attacking a wounded flay beast as soon as they deal with any other prey.

entries.name: Lonely Hunters
entries: Flay beasts almost always hunt alone and remain alone for most of their lives. They are hermaphroditic and lay clutches of eggs beneath the ground. The eggs hatch within 2d4 weeks—a flay beast's first meal is often their slightly slower sibling. Those that survive are fully grown after a year. Grown flay beasts will sometimes organize into flights of 4 to 8 creatures in order to hunt something that they could not individually take down. They are found in wild areas of Termana and Asherak. There have never been any confirmed sightings on Ghelspad, despite occasional tales of of corpses bearing the marks of their attacks.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The flay beast is usually a solitary hunter and ambushes its prey, either from the sky above or by hiding in foliage until the creature is close enough for an effective pounce attack. Once it reveals itself, it is relentless in its attacks and will use its pounce attack indiscriminately, even if provokes other attacks. They fight to the death, because a wounded flay beast is simply another meal to a healthy one.

trait.name: Deadly Fervor
entries: A creature slain by the Flesh Corruption feature decomposes at an unnaturally accelerated rate, reduced to a pool of putrefied muck after {@dice 2d6} minutes. A remove curse cast upon the body negates this effect. A gentle repose spell halts decomposition as well, but its duration is reduced to 24 hours when cast on a body slain by Flesh Corruption.

trait.name: Disease Immunity
entries: The flesh corruptor is immune to disease.

trait.name: Septic Aura
entries: Creatures within 10 feet of the flesh corruptor suffer a weakened resistance to necrotic damage. Creatures within the aura that are normally immune to necrotic damage instead have only resistance to necrotic, and those that normally have resistance to necrotic lose that resistance.

action.name: Flesh Corruption
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) necrotic damage, and the target must succeed a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw against disease or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

A flesh corruptor is a pitiful creature, a vaguely humanoid walking mass of decay. Oozing sores and seeping wounds run rampant across its exposed flesh, and great, yellowish blisters cover its hands and feet. Its hunched posture and cowl hide its face, and much of its body is concealed by a leper's rags and tattered robes.

entries.name: Children of Chern
entries: Flesh corruptors were created by Chern, and they are referred to in some old texts as "Chern's children." The titan crafted his children to destroy whatever they touched by putrefying it. He also made sure that none of those killed would be raised to plague him again by giving the flesh corruptors an appetite for putrefied remains.

entries.name: Hidden in Plain Sight
entries: Some flesh corruptors can still be found wandering the Mourning Marshes, especially along the borders of Vesh, although they have been discovered in many other regions as well. Cunning, the flesh corruptors hide by joining roving leper bands or other groups of poor, sick, and disenfranchised folk, following them from city to city. If any of the unfortunate wanderers ever notice their numbers shrinking, most assume they have simply lost another fellow to their ailments (or perhaps to predators, or simply to the elements).

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Flesh corrupters cover themselves in the robes of beggars and penitents in order to hide their sores and diseased flesh. They slowly prey on the poor and diseased. If exposed, they lash out, trying to slay their foes quickly so that nothing will remain of them.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The swarm has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and rely on smell.

trait.name: Scout
entries: Flesh strippers often send one of their own from the swarm to perform the initial bite on a victim. Treat this individual as a Tiny creature with 1 ({@dice 1d4 - 1}) hit points and a bite ({@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit 1 piercing damage + poison). This individual flesh stripper bites and injects poison into a creature for the swarm to feast upon later.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny flesh stripper. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) piercing damage and the target must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned}. While {@condition poisoned}, the creature becomes completely numb to pain, pressure, and even temperature. It suffers disadvantage on Dexterity checks, Dexterity-based attack rolls, and Dexterity saving throws. It is immune to the Incapacitated, Stunned, and Unconscious conditions and, if reduced to 0 hit points, is automatically stable.

The poison effect lasts for {@dice 2d4} hours. Numbed creatures do not notice being injured unless they visually witness the injury, hear it, or observe some other phenomenon (such as their bodies moving from the concussion of a bludgeoning blow). GMs are advised to track hit point loss for numbed creatures and keep such totals a secret.

Flesh strippers are horrid pack rodents which are a bane to wild animal herds and domesticated livestock across the Scarred Lands. Packs of the hungry beasts have even been known to prey on other predators and humanoid travelers. They resemble small, sleek rats with short, coarse fur that varies from ran to dark brown to black. They have powerful rear legs which propel them into amazing jumps, thus earning them the nickname "flying wraths" when a swarm of them are seen bounding through the tall grass toward their prey.

entries.name: Insidious swarm
entries: Flesh strippers usually send a single rat to anesthetize a creature. Once the creature no longer feels pain, the rest of the pack swarms it and feeds without the creature realizing that the flesh is being picked from its bones.

entries.name: Prized venom
entries: Flesh strippers drool profusely as their venom is carried in their saliva. Herbalists and doctors pay a much as five gold for a vial of flesh stripper saliva, as it makes an excellent topical anesthetic.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: A flesh stripper swarm typically has a single pack member bite potential prey. The swarm then waits for the anesthetic to work and for the prey to forget about the initial attack before feasting on the unaware creature.

monster.name: Flesh Crawler
languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The fleshcrawler can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check. It uses its hand and feet tethers (see next entry) in order to climb.

trait.name: Tethers of Sinew
entries: The fleshcrawler has chitinous sheaths in its hands and feet that hold grisly lengths of flesh tipped with barbed spikes. Its tongue also functions as a tether. It can shoot these tethers out at a target as action (see below) and if it chooses to detach a tether it can serve as a very strong rope (50 ft. in length). The fleshcrawler can produce an unlimited amount of tethers.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The fleshcrawler attacks with two of its limb tethers (any combination of hands or feet) and then attacks with either its mouth tether or its bite.

action.name: Limb Tether
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 25/50 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage. and the target must make a {@dc 11} Strength saving throw or be moved 25 feet closer to the fleshcrawler. The target is {@condition grappled} by the limb tether (escape {@dc 11} and the target takes 1 piercing damage from removing the barbs). Each limb tether can grapple a separate target.

action.name: Mouth Tether
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 25/50 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition paralyzed}. A {@condition paralyzed} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the effect on a success.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition paralyzed}. A {@condition paralyzed} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the effect on a success.

This creature is a humanoid with black veins showing through unwholesomely dead-white flesh. Its skin is wrapped tightly over its musculature and when it grins it shows a mouth-full of teeth and a curiously coiled tongue. It wears black leather armor and sports an array of ritualistic scars, brands and piercings.

entries.name: Demon-born
entries: Fleshcrawlers were once wicked humans who made dark bargains and ultimately were taken to the Abyssal Caldera, where demon lords made them undead and gave them dark gifts. They are sent back to the Scarred Lands as snatchers, bounty hunters, or retrievers for the demons.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Fleshcrawlers use their tethers of sinews much as spiders use strands of silk, and they strategize well in three dimensions. They may hang from their foot tethers above doorways and attack their prey from above, or they may use them to climb walls, pull down a wall on opponents, or disarm an opponent. Fleshcrawlers like to prepare ambushes for their chosen prey. When hunting in a group, fleshcrawlers use pack tactics and work together like a well-oiled machine. Some have even been known to carry others on their backs, allowing the carried fleshcrawler to make five tether attacks.

trait.name: Fire Form
entries: The forge wight can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing. A creature that touches the forge wight or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

trait.name: Forge Bound
entries: The forge wight is bound to its forge and cannot leave that location. If the forge is very large, then the wight can move its normal speed of 40 feet within the confines of the forge, but it cannot leave the forge itself.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: The forge wight sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light out in an additional 10 feet.

trait.name: Water Susceptibility
entries: For every gallon of water splashed on the forge wight, it takes {@damage 1d4} cold damage.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) fire damage. If the target is a creature or a flammable object, it ignites. Until a creature takes an action to douse the fire, the target takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage at the start of each of its turns.

action.name: Heat Metal
entries: The forge wight chooses a manufactured metal object, such as a metal weapon or a suit of heavy or medium metal armor, that it can see within 60 feet. The object glows red-hot. Any creature in physical contact with the object takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) fire damage. If a creature is holding or wearing the object and takes the damage from it, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or drop the object if it can. If it doesn't drop the object, the creature has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the start of the forge wight's next turn.

Forge wights (a misnomer, for they are not undead spirits) are elemental creatures trapped in cold forges abandoned by the ages, eager to lash out at any unwary soul that passes too close. They appear as an eerily flickering tongue of pale, ghostly flame dancing in the otherwise cold forge.

The forge wight uses heat to torment and kill its victims. It vents its anger on any mortal that stays within range, but can be placated momentarily if Thulkas is propitiated and hot coals or the like are tossed into the forge. As soon as the coals die out, however, the spirit resumes its attacks, likely angrier than before.

entries.name: Spawn of Thulkas
entries: In ancient times, master smiths across the land kept their forges hot through sacrifice to Thulkas, titan of iron and fire. In return, he would send a forge wight to inhabit the smith's forge and keep it burning. Unfortunately, the world changed; titans fell and the old smiths died. A few of these inhabited forges remain, though, in the depths of shattered fortresses or in towns long deserted, and the fire spirits trapped within are bitter from their long, cold imprisonment. An individual versed in the rites of Thulkas might perform the ceremony to free a forge wight from its prison, but there are likely very few still alive who know such lore.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The forge wight strikes out by using heat metal liberally on the gear of any who approach without making the proper obeisance. It can never leave its forge, but if a target gets close enough, the wight attacks.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Garabrud fails a Wisdom saving throw while hunting prey, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Persistent
entries: Garabrud is always aware of the location of his prey, as long as they are on the same plane, and he is unaffected by magical attempts to block scrying.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Garabrud makes one bite attack and two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) slashing damage.

legendary.name: Bite
entries: Garabrud makes a single bite attack.

legendary.name: Unchained
entries: Garabrud frees himself from one condition, magical or mundane, that restricts his movement.

legendary.name: Lick Wounds (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Garabrud heals himself for 28 ({@dice 8d6}) hit points.
The wizard Dolomar, by Hound pursued, hid himself in Burok Tom. Twelve months burrowed Garabrud, at the roots of bedrock town. ‘Til nightmares broke the wizard's will, and madness bore him down.
The gigantic mastiff is clearly nothing of natural origin. Standing taller than a man at its shoulder, this dreaded beast has a pelt of inky blackness and eyes that shine with ancient knowledge.

entries.name: Titan's Best Friend
entries: Garabrud is the only known survivor out of the three dread mastiffs that once served Gaurak. The legend of the Obsidian Hound is chronicled by the bard Adrometus, whose ballads tell of the Hound tirelessly pursuing his prey, across continents, seas, and time. The bard proposed no explanation for how or why Garabrud decides to pursue his quarry, although it has been noted that his victims are often those who have angered or disappointed the god Chardun.

entries.name: Ill Omens.
entries: No normal or magical means can hide the Hound's prey, though he might be outrun...for a while. His coming is presaged, only to his prey, by nightmares of being run down by a howling beast, with the intensity of these dreams increasing as the Hound nears.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: When Garabrud is on the hunt nothing can distract him from his path, although he may pause to deal with genuine threats. In combat he is single-minded, focusing only his target. Once his quarry is dead he will often linger in the area for a while, if food is to be had, hunting and sleeping as a normal beast.

trait.name: Disease Immunity
entries: The gauntling is immune to disease.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The gauntling is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gauntling makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

Although Gaurak remains buried, his cruel will remains. The wretched creatures known as gauntlings are what remains of fatlings who reached too far and attempted to partake too heavily of their titanic master's essence. Gauntlings are doomed to a life of endless hunger, devouring everything in their path, desperately attempting to regain Gaurak's favor.

Emaciated, virtually skeletal, gauntlings are disgusting creatures half again as tall as a human, yet gaunt and crooked, with nearly transparent skin. Their mouths are abnormally large, filled with mismatched teeth of different shapes and sizes.

entries.name: Failed Spawn
entries: Gauntlings are driven by hunger and the desire to redeem themselves in Gaurak's and other titanspawns' eyes. All they eat is a tribute to the titan, but their ravenous hunger can never be satiated; no matter how much a gauntling consumes, no flesh is ever added to its wasted frame. Other servants of Gaurak feel contempt, or at best pity for gauntlings. The thought of one so honored falling so low is generally repulsive to them.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Although they have lost most of their creator's blessings, including access to spells and spell-like abilities, gauntlings remain formidable opponents. Any living creature is considered food for the gauntling, who attacks with blind ferocity.

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

trait.name: Death Spray
entries: The instant a poisonbearer is killed or destroyed, the pustules on its skin all burst simultaneously, so that all creatures within 5 feet of it take 33 ({@damage 6d10}) poison damage, or half if they make a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw. Each creature affected must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until it takes a long rest. Should the target die while {@condition poisoned}, then it rises the next midnight as a poisonbearer ghoul.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The poisonbearer ghoul makes three attacks: two with its claws and one with its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) piercing damage and 6 ({@damage 2d10}) poison damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until it takes a long rest. Should the target die while {@condition poisoned}, then it rises the next midnight as a poisonbearer ghoul.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d4 + 2}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature other than an elf or undead, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Spit {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 5/20 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 4d10}) poison damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until it takes a long rest. Should the target die while {@condition poisoned}, then it rises the next midnight as a poisonbearer ghoul.

The poisonbearer ghoul is yet another undead creation of the Ghoul King, lord of the Isle of the Dead. This ghoulish being is even more disgusting than its typical cousins, for it is covered in broken, oozing pustules.

entries.name: Feverish Bite
entries: The substance exuded by the creature's diseased kin can transfer its horrible form of ghoul fever. It also has a magical poison it produces in its mouth, which it can spit at foe or transfer with a bite and which resists magical attempts to cure it.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: A poisonbearer often begins by spitting its poison at one or more targets and then charging in to attack with tooth and claw. Poisonbearer ghouls are fearless in combat, fighting to the last they are fanatical in their devotion to their dark master, and willingly allow themselves to be destroyed in order to spread their horrid disease.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The celestian's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}). It can cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

trait.name: Cloud Form
entries: The celestian can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The celestian makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 4d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be pushed 5 feet away from the celestian and knocked {@condition prone}.

In the eyes of the gods, the giants were all titanspawn, and they were justly punished after the defeat of their titan masters. The storm god Enkili passed down a most ironic punishment to the Hundred-Hand Ones, a cadre of the most magically gifted and most arrogant clouddwelling giants, for the role they played in the Divine War. The Trickster tore their physical forms asunder, making them as hollow as the wind. Thus, these giants, who had formerly crushed dwarves with one blow of their mighty fists, were reduced to cloudy, ephemeral beings, doomed to an eternity as strange creatures of the clouds and mists.

A celestian appears as giant, translucent, vaguely humanoid form, its cloudlike, amorphous body wavering and shifting as it moves. Huge crystal blue eyes stare down with a cold, startlingly fierce intelligence.

entries.name: Accursed Ones
entries: The celestians, as they are now known, are not as dim-witted as some of their gigantic brethren. Since the Divine War, they have adapted to their new cloudlike state and learned to use their magical gifts in ways appropriate to their forms. Their transformation has only increased their fury, so the celestians spread destruction wherever they go.

entries.name: Vengeful and Bitter
entries: The celestians' curse has created a great deal of tension between them and the rest of giant-kind, who usually consider them weak and pathetic. On those rare occasions when they cross paths, clashes between giants and celestians are common, and marvelous to behold. The true focus of celestians' ire, however, remains directed toward the gods and their servants. They are as bitter as the titans themselves, and they abhor any priests, paladins, or other divine spellcasters they encounter, targeting such opponents before all others.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Celestian giants will use their spells and their slam attacks against a foe. They prefer high places with narrow paths, where knocking someone down and pushing them 5 feet away can be the difference between being safely on the path and falling for hundreds of feet.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: While out of water, the flayed giant can hold its breath for 10 minutes.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The flayed giant can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The flayed giant makes two trident attacks.

action.name: Trident
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) piercing damage, or 18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) piercing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) piercing damage.

A flayed giant's skin is reddish, the color of fresh blood, yet semi-transparent and scaly. It has gills like those of a fish on its neck and shoulders, and fins protrude at odd angles from its extremities. It wields a massive trident nearly twice the length of a human.

entries.name: Spawn of Kadum
entries: Once favored warriors of Kadum, giants roamed the hills and mountains of Ghelspad as they wished, crushing the diminutive soldiers of the gods much as a child would squash an ant. Then the Day of Bleeding came, when the insolent gods opened Kadum's chest and bound the Mountainshaker to the bottom of the deepest ocean chasm. The puny races then rose up against the giants, driving many of them from their steadings and caverns.

Without the power of Kadum to support them, these newly homeless giants became easy prey. A great number were forced to take refuge in the bloody sea that had become their master's resting place, and thanks to their patron's potent blood, they mutated quickly to adapt to their new home.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: While not known for their intelligence, flayed giants are relatively cunning. Most often they wait below the water for a ship to pass overhead. At the right moment, they swim upward and pierce the hull of the ship with their huge tridents. While the ship's crew tends to the damage, the flayed giants then attempt latch onto the vessel, using their body weight to capsize it.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The spider-eye goblin has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The goblin can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The spider-eye goblin makes two claw attacks. If both claws hit, the goblin can then make one bite attack against that target.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) slashing damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw, taking 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If this poison damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, the target is stable but {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour, even after regaining hit points, and is {@condition paralyzed} while {@condition poisoned} in this way.

action.name: Dart
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

Goblinoids were among the titans' first attempts at creating humanoids. They fell somewhat short of being a desirable servitor race and were soon forgotten. Over time, many tribes soaked up aspects of the primordial Scarn, evolving into the numerous varieties of goblinoid races that exist in present times.

A typical spider-eye goblin has four long, slender arms ending in wicked claws, along with a bizarre array of eight eyes above its fanged maw. It wears scraps of cloth and bits of polished stone, and it scampers about easily on one of its pairs of arms and its legs.

Spider-eye goblins speak their own language, a debased dialect of Goblin blended with a smattering of Titan Speech and some crude words from the Ledean tongue. Their speech is also punctuated with odd clicks and hisses. In combat, they have evolved a clicking and chittering battle language, but also enjoy taunting their opponents in their nasty version of Ledean phrases and insults, of which most spidereye goblins know at least a few.

entries.name: Twisted Spiderkin
entries: Spider-eye goblins make their lairs in deep, dark places far enough from divine races that they can't easily be routed, but close enough that they can still send long-range raiding parties from time to time. Their typical ruling structure is a matriarchy, with a female witch most often ruling the group. Any sizable spider-eye goblin tribe keeps giant spiders as guardian beasts if not as trained mounts.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Spider-eye tactics rely on ambush, making use of their natural climbing ability to hide in the tree canopy or on cavern ceilings, where they rain javelins and darts upon their prey. They are hostile and ferocious, but not particularly courageous; in an extended fight, or in a battle against foes more numerous than themselves, a leader-less gang demonstrates typical goblin cowardice. In defense of their lair, however, they are fearless. Though not bright, they are cunning with traps.

monster.name: Hive Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical weapons that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The hive golem's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Berserk
entries: When a hive golem is reduced to 51 or fewer hit points, is immersed in water, or receives a critical hit, it goes permanently berserk, breaking free of its creator's control. While berserk it attacks random targets, its slam attacks do additional damage (see below), and its Swarm ability affects all creatures.

trait.name: Self-Repair
entries: The hive golem regenerates 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the golem is immersed in water this trait doesn't function at the start of next turn. The golem is destroyed only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The golem is surrounded by an angry, stinging swarm. Any creature that attacks it and ends its turn within 10 feet of the golem must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) piercing damage and until the end of its next turn can't take reactions and has disadvantage on attack rolls. A strong wind will prevent this ability from functioning on the golem's next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hive golem makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage or 17 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage if the golem is berserk.

variant.name: Beehive Golem
entries: Beehive golems are a composite of beeswax honeycombs and wood.

entries.name: Cold Hating
entries: If the beehive golem takes cold damage its SelfRepair and Swarm abilities do not function until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Sticky
entries: When the beehive golem is struck with a melee weapon the attacker must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw; on a failure the weapon sticks to the golem. The attacker may use an action to attempt to pull the weapon free, requiring a successful DC 15 Strength ability check.

variant.name: Termite Mound Golem
entries: Termite mound golems are large constructs of hardened brown clay. They are bulky figures without necks, faces, or fingers, having the least humanoid shape. The gnolls that inhabit the Centaur Plains are particularly noted for sending termite mound golems against their Ulante neighbors.

entries.name: Packed Earth
entries: The termite mound golem has an Armor Class of 18.

entries.name: Earthen
entries: Any spell that affects earth or stone will suppress the golem's Self-Repair until the end of its next turn.

variant.name: Wasp Nest Golem
entries: Wasp nest golems are paper and mud constructs. The constant drone of wasps surrounds them, making them easy to notice at a distance.

entries.name: Poison
entries: A creature that fails it saving throw against the golem's Swarm ability must also make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw. On a failure the creature is poisoned for one minute; on a success the creature is immune to this effect for 24 hours.

entries.name: Vulnerable to Fire
entries: The wasp nest golem is vulnerable to fire damage, and fire damage prevents its Self-Repair from functioning until the end of its next turn.

This creature is only vaguely humanoid in shape, with a rough skin formed of several materials. Its thick, malformed limbs end in heavy hands and feet. From a distance it seems to be surrounded by a cloud of wispy vapor or smoke, but closer this can be seen for what it is: a flying swarm of busy, angry insects.

entries.name: Home on the Move
entries: Hive golems are a nasty surprise for anyone who intrudes into gnoll territories in the jungles and plains of Termana. They are insect hives formed into large humanoid shapes and animated by an elemental spirit. Each one carries within it swarms of insects that defend the golem and repair damage to the hive. Gnoll druids create these golems to defend their sacred sites and villages and as engines of destruction when they make war on neighboring tribes. Hive golems differ depending on the species of insect that inhabits the golem.

entries.name: Fear of Water
entries: Immersion in water suppresses the hive golem's ability to repair itself, and the golems are consequently wary of going anywhere near bodies of water. They will not willingly cross any water deeper than a few inches.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Unless directed otherwise by their creator, hive golems lumber into combat and use their slam attacks against any foes that come within reach. They will often head into the largest concentration of opponents, where their swarm of stinging insects can do the most damage. Hive golems are usually used to support and protect gnolls, and are rarely encountered alone.

monster.name: Lead Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical weapons that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Impenetrable
entries: The lead golem and any objects or creatures it carries are immune to divination spells.

trait.name: Inertia
entries: The lead golem has advantage on any ability checks or saving throws to resist being moved against its will.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two slam attacks or one slam and one stomp attack.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and the creature must succeed at a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Stomp
entries: The lead golem steps on a Medium or smaller creature, or a Large {@condition prone} creature, within 5 feet of it. The creature takes 36 ({@damage 8d8}) damage, or half damage on a successful {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw.

reaction.name: Pest Control
entries: When a creature falls {@condition prone} within 5 feet of the golem it may stomp the target.

The footsteps of this massive automaton shake the ground. Its dull gray and armored surface has been forged into the shape of a giant human, more than twice as tall as any man. Its mouth is sculpted into a fearsome visage, as if roaring a battle cry, but no sound escapes from this lifeless metal colossus.

entries.name: Tireless Laborers
entries: The dark elves of Dier Drendal are especially fond of creating lead golems, often fashioning them with massive clawed hands useful for digging tunnels, and using them in attacks on the dwarves of Burok Torn. They follow only the commands of their creators, and although they can understand only the most basic commands, with time and effort they can be trained to mindlessly carry out more complex tasks.

entries.name: Unstoppable Force, Immovable Object
entries: Lead Golems are created from at least 15,000 pounds of lead. This crushing weight can inflict horrendous damage to structures or opponents. The golem will sink at least part way into anything softer than densely packed earth, and even in soft stone will leave discernible footprints.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The dense lead golem will usually attack whoever is close at hand and did the most damage to it since its last turn. If their first slam misses they will slam a second time; otherwise they will use stomp as their second attack. Two or more golems will position themselves so that when one knocks an enemy prone they can all stomp on it.

monster.name: Mithril Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical weapons that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Defender of the Meek
entries: A friendly creature who touches the mithril golem, in either its active or dormant state, gains the benefit of sanctuary (spell save {@dc 20}).

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the mithril golem fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The mithril golem's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 18} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}43 ({@damage 6d10 + 10}) bludgeoning damage. If the golem hits a creature with two slam attacks in one turn the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 25}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}. A creature that is being {@condition grappled} by the golem at the end of its turn takes 44 ({@damage 8d10}) bludgeoning damage, or half as much damage on a successful {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 18} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}54 ({@damage 8d10 + 10}) bludgeoning damage. The golem can only stomp creatures that are Large or smaller.

legendary.name: Stomp Attack
entries: The golem makes a stomp attack.

An awesome figure towers overhead, dwarfing nearby buildings. Its gleaming metallic surface is marred only by furrows dug by the flailing of a titan. The colossal figure is forged in the human heroic ideal and its presence conveys the splendor of the gods who forged it.

entries.name: Kadum's Bane
entries: Priests of Corean hold that the mithril golem was forged by their god to use against the titan Kadum in the Divine War, and that the golem was able to hold Kadum by his tail just long enough for the bestial titan to be gutted and chained by the gods. Its purpose fulfilled, the golem was abandoned on a cliff overlooking the Blood Sea. The priests built a temple around the towering figure, the city of Mithril grew around the temple, and for 150 years the golem has not moved. But the faithful have no doubt their god will rouse the golem to life again one day to defend their city.

entries.name: Great Strides Towards Victory
entries: The colossal mithril golem towers over not only friend and foe, but also over most buildings and trees. Should it move, its massive stride would allow it to walk as fast as a man can sprint, and to step over obstacles with ease.

entries.name: Swords from Appendages
entries: Legend has it that the priests of Corean prayed for weapons to aid them in their attempts to cleanse the Blood Sea coast of titanspawn, and soon thereafter a single finger fell from the golem in their temple. From this finger the swords of the paladins of Mithril were forged.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The mithril golem will usually attack the most threatening enemy close at hand and pummel it into dust, then find another target. Once it gets a grapple on an enemy it will try to hold on, causing damage each round.

monster.name: Gallows Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands all languages but does not speak

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's attacks are magical.

trait.name: Persistent
entries: The gallows golem is always aware of the location of its prey, as long as they are on the same plane, and it is unaffected by magical attempts to block scrying.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gallows golem makes two slam attacks and then one attack with its noose.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Noose
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}), unable to speak and suffocating. On subsequent rounds the golem can use its action to deal 12 ({@damage 1d12 + 6}) bludgeoning damage to a creature caught in the noose. It regains the same amount of hit points.

Most golems are created with powerful magics and intense rituals. But spontaneous golems arise by other means—great passion and intense feelings invest a spontaneous golem with an animus, a driving force, instead of the arcane weavings that provide the same for traditional golems.

This golem (also called a Wooden Hangman by those few who know of its existence) exists to kill. But it is fueled by the overwhelming hatred that mobs feel when seeking a scapegoat. It cares nothing for justice, only to fulfill the mob's need to see someone die in punishment for some outrage, real or imagined.

The gallows golem is humanoid only in the roughest sense. Constructed of wooden planks, rusted nails, and old rope, it appears almost like some great marionette. It stands roughly 12 feet high and weighs well over 500 pounds. Its arms are far longer than its legs, nearly reaching the ground even when it stands upright, and it often moves on all fours when traveling great distances. Its most hideous feature, though, is what passes as its head. A thick wooden beam the length of a man's arm juts forth from atop the golem. At the end of that bar hangs an old, frayed noose, which swings like a pendulum when it turns its "neck" side to side. It almost appears as though the golem is looking about through the eyes of the last person to die in that noose, though the rope is empty.

entries.name: Endless Hunter
entries: Although most of its movements are abrupt and somewhat rough, the gallows golem walks with a smooth gait, and is capable of running tirelessly when seeking its next victim. It smells of old, musty wood, tainted faintly with the coppery tang of spilled blood.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Unless it is attempting to kill the specific victim to whom it's been drawn, the gallows golem fights only to defend itself, or to destroy anyone who attempts to keep it from its chosen victim. It uses its noose attack only against its intended victim.

monster.name: Serpent Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands all languages but does not speak

trait.name: Hypnotize
entries: The swaying motion of the serpent golem can put other creatures into a trance. Each creature viewing the serpent golem for the first time must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature is {@condition stunned}. On a success, the creature is immune to this effect for 24 hours. A creature can spend its action shaking a creature {@condition stunned} by this effect, the affected creature can then repeat its saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the effect and becoming immune for 24 hours on a success.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The serpent golem makes two biting fists attacks.

action.name: Biting Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, 4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) poison damage and if the target is a creature it must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute.

The druids of Mormo use the magic granted to them by their hideous mother to create these terrifying monsters. Serpent golems are writhing, man-shaped piles of venomous snakes, even more potent than the lesser venom golems also manufactured by Mormo's druids. Serpent golems defend the hidden shrines to Mormo that dot the Hornsaw Forest and the wastelands of Ghelspad.

entries.name: Born in Fear
entries: A serpent golem is created through the use of dark rituals in which a victim (perhaps alive, perhaps not) is submerged in a pit of vipers, cobras and asps. These serpents provide the bulk of the golem's form, writhing around the humanoid underneath.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Being non-intelligent constructs, serpent golems pursue their opponents with frightening determination. They use their hypnotize ability to winnow opponents down and then attack those that are still moving, lashing out with a fist made of poisonous fangs.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The high gorgon is a 11th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, or {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). The gorgon knows the following sorcerer and warlock spells:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The high gorgon has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Serpentine Ancestry
entries: Magic can't put the high gorgon to sleep.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The high gorgon makes two scimitar attacks and one Serpents attack.

action.name: Scimitar
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Serpents
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 21 ({@damage 6d6}) poison damage.

entries.name: Scarn Gorgon
entries: One of the most twisted legacies the titans left behind are the gorgons. There are actually two varieties of gorgons in the Scarred Lands: the bestial {@creature low gorgon|SLCC}, and the humanoid {@creature high gorgon|SLCC}. Although they seem as different as humans are from lions, both varieties of gorgon are actually aberrations, and repulsively, they are also completely interfertile—the males of either species can fertilize females of either kind. In either case, they lay clutches of up half a dozen eggs, one in five of which typically hatches into a high gorgon, while the rest become low gorgons.

entries.name: Spawn of Mormo
entries: The Serpent Mother birthed these wretched creatures shortly before the Titanswar began, and they served their mother obediently throughout the war. They were arguably her most successful and terrifying creation, and today the gorgons work ceaselessly to restore their witch mother.

entries.name: High Gorgon
entries: A high gorgon looks like a hairless human with faintly elfin features, yet there is something indeterminably cold about its behavior. Within the smooth flesh of its abdomen lies a twisting mass of proboscises or tentacles shaped like fanged serpents. The gorgon can reveal these appendages via a bizarre muscled orifice, a barely discernible vertical slash like a tight-lipped mouth. When revealed, these serpentine appendages lash out through the wet crimson gap, their fangs dripping with venom. High gorgons have their own unique tongue, derived from Titan Speech, which they keep secret from all others except their low gorgon brethren.

entries.name: Talented Deceivers
entries: High gorgons don't have a proper culture of their own, really; they imitate human society as best they can. Within human society, high gorgons often pose as members of obscure human cults, which seek to convince adherents to grant a little more indulgence to their sect's unusual customs. They have no real allies among the other races, but they have been known to hire or cooperate with various goblins, werewolves, and even Unredeemed asaatthi.

entries.name: Secretive Arcanists
entries: High gorgons gather in small cabals to exchange information and magic, and they particularly prize any rumors that might lead to another piece of Mormo's dissevered remains. The Hornsaw Forest is a place of pilgrimage to high gorgons, who visit an underground temple there dedicated to the Witch Queen's spilled blood.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: High gorgons rarely fight directly, preferring to use their servants and low gorgons instead. However, they are capable warriors, using their spells and scimitar to great effect. Once the gorgon has the upper hand, it will not be afraid to reveal the serpents within, as it is certain that no one will survive the fight to report that they are more than what they seem.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The low gorgon has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The low gorgon has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Serpentine Ancestry
entries: Magic can't put the low gorgon to sleep.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The low gorgon makes four attacks: a bite, two claws, and a tail slam.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) acid damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Scarn Gorgon
entries: One of the most twisted legacies the titans left behind are the gorgons. There are actually two varieties of gorgons in the Scarred Lands: the bestial {@creature low gorgon|SLCC}, and the humanoid {@creature high gorgon|SLCC}.
